POST OF MANAGEMENT SERVICE OFFICER: VACANCIES
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the number of vacancies existing in the post of Management Service Officer of the Combined Service; (ii) whether he is aware that the results of the competitive examination held to recruit Management Service Officers in year 2021 have been released; (iii) the number of Management Service Officers to be recruited based on the results of the aforesaid examination; and (iv) the date they will be recruited?
( ( - ) (The Hon. Ashoka Priyantha - State Minister of Home Affairs) , , , :.
( - ) (The Hon. Sanjeeva Edirimanna on behalf of the Hon. Chinthaka Amal Mayadunna) - (1)
asked the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries:
(i) the number of coconut seedlings that have been distributed by the Coconut Cultivation Board from 2019 up to now, separately according to each district and year;
(ii) the amount spent by the Board for distribution of the said seedlings, separately for each year;
(iii) the criteria that were considered in distributing coconut seedlings; and
(iv) whether a follow-up is done regarding the progress of the seedling distribution programme?
( ( - ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga - Minister of Urban Development and Housing and Chief Government Whip) , * .
( - () ) (The Hon. Sanjeeva Edirimanna on behalf of the Hon. (Mrs.) Kokila Gunawardene) - (1)
ask the Minister of Power and Energy:
(i) the number of employees of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation who have been subjected to political victimization since 2015;
(ii) whether formal investigations have been conducted into the aforementioned political victimization;
(iii) the number of workers who have been granted relief, out of the number of persons who have been subjected to victimization so far; and
(iv) the number of persons still in need of relief?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) , * .
COURSES OF NATIONAL COLLEGES OF EDUCATION: DETAILS
( - () ) (The Hon. Sanjeeva Edirimanna on behalf of the Hon. (Mrs.) Rajika Wickramasinghe) - (1)
(i) the planned intake for the National Colleges of Education in future;
(ii) the date on which appointments will be granted to the students of Colleges of Education who have completed the courses;
(iii) the date on which the courses offered by the Colleges of Education will be upgraded to degree courses; and
(iv) whether action will be taken to award degrees to the students enrolled into the Colleges of Education in future?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) , * .
: : PRODUCTION AND EXPORT OF SHRIMP: DETAILS
( - ) (The Hon. Sanjeeva Edirimanna on behalf of the Hon. Ishak Rahuman) - (1)
(i) the areas where shrimp farming is carried out in Sri Lanka;
(ii) the annual shrimp production in Sri Lanka;
(iii) the concessions granted to the shrimp farming industry;
(iv) the measures taken to encourage shrimp farmers?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) the number of entrepreneurs engaged in shrimp farming for export purposes; (ii) the income earned from the export of shrimp from 2016 to date, separately according to each year; (iii) whether measures will be taken to increase the revenue generated from the export of shrimp; (iv) if so, the measures that will be taken in that regard?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) , * .

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) The next speaker is the Hon. Jeevan Thondaman.

( ( - ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman - Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development) Hon. Presiding Member, I must say that, today, I noticed many arguments being put forward by all the Hon. Members who spoke, those of the ruling party as well as of the Opposition. But, one interesting fact in this Debate was, everybody seemed to say that in this

particular month, so many girls were raped and in that particular month, this girl was raped by so many people and that all that was the fault of the Government; they managed to, more or less, politicize the matter. But, I feel that everyone is failing to address the elephant in the room, which is, what happens after that. I think we must address the biggest elephant in this room, which is the abortion rights in Sri Lanka. But, that is not something we are speaking about, that is not something anyone is caring to touch on and that is why we are at this place right now.

If I may say so, there are a few solutions we can adopt and in the interest of time, let me just quickly give my thoughts on it. If I can start off by saying what is important at this particular point of time, it is education and sexual education. In relation to sexual education, we must focus on comprehensive sexuality education and that is something we have been arguing about for many years but, unfortunately, we have actually not seen the light of it. It is only through CSE in schools that children and young people will develop accurate and age-appropriate knowledge, attitudes and skills, positive values such as respect for human rights, gender equality and diversity and attitudes and skills that contribute to a safe, healthy and positive relationship. CSE plays a pivotal role in the preparation of young people for a safe, productive and fulfilling life in a world where HIV, AIDS, sexually transmitted infections, unintended pregnancies and sexual and gender-based violence still pose a risk to their well-being. CSE basically empowers children to take control and make informed decisions about their sexuality and relationships, freely and responsibly.

Also, Sir, we must acknowledge the gender-based violence that takes place in this country. When it comes to violence against women in Sri Lanka, I must say that especially the male intimate partners of women are their biggest killers. It is not my opinion, but the opinion of the study done by the UNFPA and the University of Kelaniya in 2021. Sir, 62 per cent of homicides of Sri Lankan women are committed by their intimate partner, ex-partner or a family member, more than 50 per cent of murders of Sri Lankan women are committed by their husbands and 84 per cent of Sri Lankan women killed were attacked in their own home by somebody they know or somebody of their family. Again, all these are not my opinions, but are revelations from that study done by the UNFPA and the University of Kelaniya two years ago. Only 5 per cent of cases concerning women murdered between 2013 to 2017 were ever concluded in court. Men regularly argue in court that their wife or girlfriend provoked them to murder their partner. An unsound mind and mental illnesses have often been successful defences in those matters. So, really, the safety the Judiciary provides women is questionable; their protection is questionable. Sir, I would also like to say that as far as the police officers are concerned - again, if the hat fits, they can wear it - they have expressed bias and more sympathy towards the narrative which I have mentioned as opposed to the victim, who is either assaulted or dead.
I would also like to say that assault of not just women, but also children is a sensitive issue, which no one speaks

about. Unfortunately, we have to speak about it because we need to bring about a change, if we are going to protect the next generation. Every two hours, a child is sexually molested in this country! People may not admit it, they may not want to hear it or may not want to say it, but that is a fact and that must be accepted. One thousand seven hundred and twenty one is the number of children below the age of 16 who were raped, and that was reported in 2021. There are unreported cases, too, my fellow Members.

Then, seven to 10 years is the average length of a child rape trial in Sri Lanka. Seven to ten years! Basically, if a child gets raped, only when that child becomes a major will the case conclude. That also, we do not know whether it is going to be in the childs favour because we have a history of protecting the oppressors.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Minister, you have two more minutes. ( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) I am sure I could get more than that, Sir, as you are my friend.

And, I would like to say that only 23 per cent - [Interruption.] Excuse me, I am speaking for the majority of the population in this country. Therefore, I think I can take some more time. I am not speaking about politics and wasting time like half the Members who spoke before me did.

Only 23 per cent of our total school strength has child protection committees. That needs to be increased; awareness needs to be created. I am sure our responsible State Minister, the Hon. (Mrs.) Geetha Samanmale Kumarasinghe, would be able to take a step forward.

Sir, I would also like to bring up another sensitive matter. That is, every 90 minutes, a woman is raped in Sri Lanka. These are not official statistics, but outcomes from surveys. Most women who are raped do not report it. But, we cannot use that as an excuse and say that women are not being raped.

In a 2013 UN survey on male sexual violence in Sri Lanka, it was revealed, I am sorry to say, that 15 per cent of Sri Lankan men admitted to having raped a woman at least once and 1 in 10 men admitted to raping them more than once. Forty per cent of men who admitted to raping women said they committed their first rape before they turned 20 years! A majority of men who admitted to rape, according to that study, said they did so because they were entitled to. Twenty per cent of those men said they raped because it was "fun" or because they were "bored". Also, from among those who admitted to rape, according to the survey, only 3 per cent were arrested! So, you must really look back at these numbers. I am not giving my
opinion, but, again, these are numbers based on surveys, reports and studies, which have always been available to us, but which we have not acted on.

Despite these alarming statistics on rape and sexual violence, women are often blamed and punished for it. The criminalization of abortion is a major example for that. With that being said, I would also like to say that according to a 2016 estimate done by the Ministry of Health in Sri Lanka, approximately 658 abortions take place a day in this country. That is, close to 250,000 abortions per year and 250,000 Sri Lankan women whose lives are endangered or at risk.

Then, if we take the impact on maternal health, a research from 2015 indicates that unsafe abortions are the third most common cause for perinatal deaths in Sri Lanka, accounting to 10 to 13 per cent of maternal fatalities. This highlights a serious health risk. With regard to legal restrictions, Sri Lanka has some of the most restrictive abortion laws in the world. Abortion is illegal unless it is necessary to save the life of the mother. Engaging in abortion is a criminal act under Sri Lanka's Penal Code and is punishable with imprisonment, ranging from three to ten years with or without a fine.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Minister, please wind up now. ( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) I will, Sir.

Sir, Sri Lankas achievements in maternal and child health are impressive. However, illegally induced abortions and their complications continue to be a burden on the healthcare system of this country and I am fairly sure that most of the healthcare officials will agree with me on that. The most unsafe abortions happen with women who have already had children and cannot have any more. There is this stigma in this country, where they say that we need to safeguard our culture and religions. The reality is this. Even a 1997 survey shows that more than 90 per cent of the women who wish to have abortions are married women because of poverty, because they want to go for foreign employment or due to other factors. This, again, needs to be recognized.
I am sorry, Sir, I will take a few more minutes. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) It is okay.
( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) Also, I would like to say that most of the unsafe abortions could be prevented either by the use of

medication or by preventive care. If you look at the methods of safe abortion, mainly, there are four: medical abortion, aspiration abortion, dilation and evacuation - D&E - abortion and induction abortion.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Minister, please wind up now. You have used two extra minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) Sir, I am almost done and will wind up.

Apart from that, there are certain legislative amendments which are required to address this. One is, the introduction of new child courts. The Government is already working on a new law to reform the Domestic Violence Act. There would be reforms to the marriage and divorce laws to ensure there is an easier path to divorce. No one should be forced to remain in a marriage that is either abusive or not healthy. Apart from that, rape needs to be criminalized across the board.
In the interest of time, Sir, I am tabling* my prepared speech.
I know that the Hon. Presiding Member, who is from the estate sector, will criticize me for not speaking about the estate sector.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Yes, but the time is very limited, Hon. Minister. ( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) I have already tabled my prepared speech. So, do not worry, Sir. Also, I would like to send a copy of my prepared speech to the Hon. President and his State Minister to take prompt action.
Thank you. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Premnath C. Dollawatte. You have seven minutes.

. ( . ) (The Hon. Premnath C. Dolawatte, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. Presiding Member, I really acknowledge the reforms proposed by the Hon. Jeevan Thondaman. We are also willing to take part in bringing the reforms that have been discussed.

We are afraid to talk about sexuality, Sir. We must ensure that sexual education is included in the Grade 7 Health and Physical Education Textbook and thereby, we can educate all the children in Sri Lanka about sexuality. I believe most of these child abuses occur due to lack of sexual knowledge.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Member, you have two more minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Imran Maharoof. You have seven minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Shantha Bandara.
Order, please! The Hon. Premnath C. Dolawatte will now take the Chair.
Whereupon THE HON. VELU KUMAR left the Chair, and THE HON. PREMNATH C. DOLAWATTE took the Chair.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) , . . Next, the Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam. You have nine minutes.
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Presiding Member, I am happy to follow the Hon. State Minister of Women and Child Affairs.

In the North and the East, Sir, we have over 60,000 women-headed households. As you know, the North and the East had been a war zone. There had been an immense amount of destruction of property and houses because of the nature in which the Government waged the war, and as a result, after the war ended, lack of housing became a major crisis. People had land or deeded property, but however, they did not have houses to live in.

We had the Indian Housing Scheme which, to a great extent, helped in alleviating that crisis. Then, of course, there have been several government schemes that were introduced. Unfortunately, those government schemes are based on providing funds for the building of houses, which are grossly inadequate and are released in stages. So, what happenes is, for the first stage, a certain sum is released and you are supposed to construct the house to a certain limit and it is only after that, the second tranche of funds would get released. But, when the amount of money that is released in the first instance is inadequate - more often than not, it has been grossly inadequate - then,

obviously, to proceed with that housing project, people struggle. So, what has happened over time, especially, in the case of those women-headed households, is that they are forced to take a loan to complete that first stage in order to get the second stage of funds to be released from the Government and by doing that, they get into a rut, they get into a vicious debt cycle.

Many Members here have already spoken about microfinance. Soon after the war ended, it was these finance companies which ran to the North and the East because they realized the situation. As a result of the poverty that existed, for those victims to move forward, they lavishly gave funding, which actually got people into a debt trap and they started committing suicide. They are in this situation not because their houses got destroyed due to some natural disaster or they did not have houses - they had houses - but because those were destroyed due to military action. So, at the very least, actually, they should have been compensated; for the nature of bombings that took place, they should have been compensated so that they could have built their houses. Then, those housing schemes, ideally, should have been for people who had property but who did not have a house and not for those whose houses had been destroyed. That should have been, actually, tackled separately. But, unfortunately, no Government, since the end of the war, chose to look at it that way. Therefore, I urge the lady State Minister to intervene on behalf of those women-headed households because they are extremely vulnerable and to somehow try and convince the relevant Ministries to look at this debt trap issue with regard to these housing schemes, in particular.

Then, the education system for the children in this country, Sir, very unfortunately, is not, if I may say so, geared towards the countrys development, production and economic development. There is a fair criticism that we formulate our education policies on the basis of trying to get aid from the World Bank and from the Asian Development Bank.

Also, the criticism is that we, ultimately, produce people who have qualifications as opposed to the skills that are actually relevant for this country. I think the Hon. Members in the Government side and even those in the opposited side have, on several occasions, agreed with the sentiment that our education system has to be completely overhauled. We need to produce genuine entrepreneurship, people with an investment mind, but none of which, unfortunately, happens. It is only an elite few who have access to private and foreign education institutions who eventually succeed very well in this country. It is not that we do not have the talent, but it just means that we are not providing the system with adequate capacity to produce those kinds of qualified people.

Sir, our schooling structure has cadres for counselling. If you take the North and the East, counselling is a crucial part because we have a drug problem that is rampant. If I may say with utmost responsibility, the military is involved in it. As you know, we have still not got out of

this counterinsurgency mentality, where the military also peddles drugs in the North and the East. I mean, it cannot happen without the three forces not knowing. That is the pervasive presence of the military in the North and the East and it is happening through them; it is part of this counterinsurgency. As a result, we have a very high rate of children becoming dependent on drugs and alcohol. So, counselling is crucial. Unfortunately, in our system, the counsellors in schools are not trained. They just fill the cadre. There is no specific programme for them to be trained and to be able to handle the grave situation that exists, particularly in the North and the East. As a result, we have problems like suicide attempts, social pressures and addiction problems which are not going away. Because these counsellors in the school system are not trained in the proper way, the system condemns those children who have problems further and further. Those children are not counselled to a point where they could come out of it or helped to come out of it. Instead, they are condemned to a point where they cannot go back to school. So, they fall between the stools. Therefore, it is a massive problem in the North and the East. As a result, what happens is, the whole system outcasts those young people and then, they become desperate, crimes increase and it just snowballs over and over.

I will conclude with that, Sir. Again, I have stated that the North and the East had been a war zone, that we have not recovered from the losses of the war, financially and on top of that, we have such a massive rate - 60,000 or more - of women-headed households. Therefore, it is a vulnerable part of the country. So, I appeal to the lady State Minister to use whatever influences she has with the Government and to intervene so that this grave situation is addressed. Thank you very much.

GAL OYA FARMERS AFFECTED BY DISPOSSESSION OF LAND
... ( ... ) (The Hon. S.M.M. Muszhaaraff) Sir, please give me one more minute.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) : , . ... ( ... ) (The Hon. A.L.M. Athaullah) Soil test . , ; . , , . .
alcohol . alcohol . - . , " ? , . . , . Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries .
; , , . , , , Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries . . , , . , . . .

Hon. State Minister of Finance, the Ministry of Finance has to bear the responsibility for this terrible fraud that is taking place in the name of a public-private partnership. I will read from the two Reports of the Committee on Public Enterprises, where we have repeatedly brought certain matters regarding this company to the notice of the Government and the Treasury. The Treasury is complicit in this terrible fraud that is taking place! .

You all banned ethanol imports. We use almost 20 million litres of ethanol in this country. Another 20 million litres are used in the illegal liquor trade. So, almost 40 million litres of ethanol are being used in this country. Before banning ethanol imports, you got almost Rs. 1,000 on a litre as duty. But, now, local companies do not pay duty. Today, the production cost of ethanol is just Rs. 150 per litre, whereas they are selling it in the market at Rs. 1,500, making almost a profit ten times that of the production cost! Where is that money going? If you look at the two Reports of the Committee on Public Enterprises - COPE, you will see how these companies are making super profits and in your Budget, you have not even taxed them. You must land a super tax on them.

Now, you are going to land this VAT and have landed this PAYE Tax on the poor professionals and others. Hundreds of professionals have left the country and are continuing to leave the country because of this heavy burden. You wanted only Rs. 100 billion from the PAYE Tax, whereas you have got almost Rs. 120 billion. But, if you correctly tax these companies, you could ease the burden on the people. See the amount of profit these companies are earning and they are not investing a single cent! They are lending money through their own, connected companies. They have the LOLC Finance and other connected companies, through which they are lending money and taking interest. They are lending money at exorbitant rates even to the farmers, destroying the farmers and their livelihoods. :.

If you correctly analyse the situation, the fault is with the Treasury because they are also part of this; it is a PPP and the Treasury officials are there in that company. I must also tell you - I do not want to name people - that there was a member of a leading family in this country, who was once a Minister, who had gone and sat in its Board meetings. That was handed over in 2006. Then, you can imagine what happened. From 2006 onwards, this has been happening. You, Hon. State Minister, perhaps, had been part of those administrations. You, as a poor young politician, perhaps, may not know the amount of money certain people are making out of this. : . : . , : : . .

Also, see what they did to these poor farmers! There is a very important local organization called Human Elevation Organization. The Hon. S.M.M. Muszhaaraff mentioned that. One K. Nihal Ahamed has done a very good job; he brought out the grievances of the poor farmers whose lands were grabbed to set up the Hingurana Sugar Company and the sugarcane plantations at that time, way back. They had not been paid compensation. The Hon. Member raised it today.

- - 2021 2021 : : - : . Please read these COPE Reports and see how these companies are operating. Now, they have set up a holding company. The Hingurana Sugar Company is separate. They have taken over the assets, not paid a single cent and are declaring losses every time. Fifty one per cent of the company is owned by the Treasury and the Treasury representative is going and sleeping there. GA, Ampara is also a director there. So, what is GA, Ampara doing? He has to look after the benefits of the farmers, the poor people. He does not do anything. All of them, in my opinion, are colluding in this terrible fraud that is taking place. One day, all this - these companies, the way in which they are hiding their profits and transferring the profits to the lending companies in the same group - will be brought out and they will have to pay. You know that the LOLC is a lending organization in the same group. They have made profits and earned interest, whilst the Hingurana Sugar Company has, forever, been declaring losses.

Then, what about loss of Government revenue? Having banned the import of ethanol, the Government has facilitated these people to produce ethanol locally, allowing them to make a profit ten times that of the production cost! Ethanol is sold at Rs. 1,500 a litre today. With all this happening, the Treasury is blind to this reality! : : , .

: : . Now, brown sugar is Rs. 350 a kilo. Ideally, the sugarcane price should be about Rs. 20,000 per metric ton or more. You can pay Rs. 20,000 per metric ton to the farmers, but a pittance is given to them, pushing them below the poverty line. That is the whole problem. But, the Mendis & Company, the Galoya Plantations, the Pelwatte Sugar Plantation, the Sevanagala Sugar Plantation, all are rich people; all are benefitting in a massive way.

: , : , , locally : , - - . : : . Last year alone, the LOLC has paid off their debts amounting to some seven billion rupees, all monies taken out of this! If there is a proper forensic audit done, all of this will come out.

Leave alone the Sri Lanka Cricket and its forensic audit. You must do a forensic audit on this, on what is happening in these companies. These massive companies are being allowed to make super profits. So, land a supertax on them and then, take that money. At least, you reduce the PAYE Tax and prevent the brain drain from this country. How many professionals have left the country? There are no surgeons in hospitals, no

anaesthetists in hospitals. This is happening because you all are taxing the professionals and others, whereas these big companies are getting away scot-free! Therefore, please look into all this and take some corrective action fast.
[..7.12] ( ( - ) (The Hon. Shehan Semasinghe - State Minister of Finance) , ; .

Certainly, we are working on expanding the tax net. If there are frauds happening, of course, we will ensure that all that is rectified. At the same time, Hon. Member, I must say that professionals or anybody else leaving the country is a multifaceted concern. It is not happening only because of this taxation issue. We are a bankrupt country and our economy is doing extremely bad. However, now, we are emerging from that crisis. So, we all will have to get together and ensure that the rights of the 22 million people in this country are protected. If all who can afford to leave the country do so, then what will happen to the other poor people in this country? So, let us get together and get out of this crisis. Also, if there are any wrongdoings, let us correct those.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) ,- ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) , . ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. State Minister, what we are asking is to give us an opportunity to meet you and explain this whole issue. The Hon. S.M.M. Muszhaaraff is there. The Treasury can always put pressure on these companies. They are hiding all their profits; they are making massive profits. The Treasury must be aware of this since there is a Treasury representatives in that. Therefore, give us an opportunity to come and explain to the Treasury officials what is happening there.
( ) (The Hon. Shehan Semasinghe) We will do that.
And it being past 6.30 p.m., THE HON. DEPUTY SPEAKER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 7.18 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Tuesday, 05th December, 2023, pursuant to the Resolution of Parliament of 20th November, 2023.
Corrections which Members suggest for the Final Print of their speeches should be clearly marked in their copy and
sent to the Editor of HANSARD within two weeks of receipt of the uncorrected copy.
